title: Why You Shouldn’t Ask a Charity How It Spends Your Donation
body:
Dean Karlan (@deankarlan) is a professor of economics and finance at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University and the co-director of the Global Poverty Research Lab.
When it comes to charitable giving, people want to know what their money is doing. How many lives were saved with their donation, how many children were fed with their donation.
This thinking, even if well-intentioned, puts the focus on the donor and their dollars--and not the recipient. Instead, I suggest two simple principles for donors to follow.
1.Do not ask charities what your money did.
For many nonprofits it is genuinely impossible to answer how exactly their efforts are different with those extra $10 or $1,000.
